user_input: What is the role of the School Participation Division in relation to academic year requirements?
reference_contexts: ['Chapter 1 Academic Years, Academic Calendars, Payment Periods, and Disbursements Academic Year Requirements Every eligible program must have a defined academic year. A school may have different academic years for different academic programs. For example, a school may choose to define the academic year for a term-based program differently from a non-term program. In some cases, the academic year definition must be different for different programs, such as in the case of a clock-hour program and a credit-hour program. For Title IV purposes, the academic year is defined in weeks of instructional time and credit or clock hours. The program9s academic year does not have to coincide with the school9s academic calendar (see <Academic year definition and effect on awards= later in the chapter). A school may treat two versions of the same academic program (day and night, for example) as separate programs and define different academic years for each version. If a school establishes separate versions of a program, with different academic years, but allows individual students to take courses from both versions, it must be able to demonstrate which program the student is actually enrolled in. Generally, to be considered enrolled in a particular program or version of a program, a student must be taking most of their coursework in that program. Although a school may have different academic years for different programs, it must use the same academic year definition for all Title IV awards for students enrolled in a particular program, and for all other Title IV program purposes. Weeks of Instructional Time in an Academic Year For both undergraduate and graduate programs, the law and regulations require an academic year to include a minimum number of weeks of instructional time. For a program offered in credit hours, the academic year must include at least 30 weeks of instructional time. For a program offered in clock hours, the academic year must include at least 26 weeks of instructional time. Note: See Volume 2, Chapter 2 for information about academic year requirements for direct assessment programs, which do not measure academic progress using credit or clock hours. The number of weeks of instructional time is based on the period that generally begins on the first day of classes in the academic year and ends on the last day of classes or the last day of examinations, whichever is later. Schools that provide 2- or 4-year associate or baccalaureate degree programs may apply to the Department if they want to request approval to establish a full academic year of less than 30 weeks of instructional time. The Department is permitted to grant a reduction for good cause to no less than 26 weeks of instructional time. These requests are handled on a case-by-case basis. To request approval, contact the School Participation Division that oversees your school. A listing of contact information for the regional School Participation Divisions can be found in the Knowledge Center. For all Title IV programs, a week of instructional time is any period of seven consecutive days in which 3 At least one day of regularly scheduled instruction or examinations occurs, or, after the last scheduled day of classes']
reference: The context does not specify the exact role of the School Participation Division, but it indicates that schools must contact the School Participation Division that oversees their school to request approval for establishing a full academic year of less than 30 weeks of instructional time, which the Department may grant for good cause.

user_input: What does 34 CFR 668.3(a) specify regarding the academic year minimums?
reference_contexts: ['Regulatory Citations Academic year minimums: 34 CFR 668.3(a) Weeks of instructional time: 34 CFR 668.3(b)']
reference: 34 CFR 668.3(a) pertains to the minimum number of weeks of instructional time required for an academic year.

user_input: In the context of Chapter 3, how does the inclusion of clinical work conducted outside the classroom affect the classification of standard and nonstandard terms in medical and education programs, and what are the specific criteria that determine whether such clinical work allows a term to be considered standard?
reference_contexts: ['Inclusion of Clinical Work in a Standard Term Periods of medical and education program clinical work which is conducted outside the classroom may not be included in a standard term, unless all of the following apply: All students in the program must participate in the practicum or clinical experience, and they must be required to complete the practicum or clinical experience as a condition for applying for licensure or authorization to practice the occupation they intend to pursue; The school has little or no control over the length or starting and ending dates of the practicum or clinical experience. This may be due to constraints imposed by outside licensing bodies or the need to accommodate schedules of entities with which students are being placed (e.g., school districts or hospitals); and Credit hours associated with the practicum or clinical experience must be associated with the term in which most of the training occurs, even if the starting and ending dates do not exactly align with the term dates and/or overlap with another term. If the clinical work meets all the above criteria, terms which include such clinical work are not required to be considered nonstandard, nor are such programs required to be considered non-term, even if the clinical work overlaps another term. This flexibility is limited to required clinical periods associated with standard term programs in medicine (including, but not limited to, allopathic, osteopathic, nursing, veterinary, dentistry, pharmacy, and physical therapy), and student teaching required to obtain a state teaching certificate. See Volume 8, Chapter 3 for additional guidance on certain exceptions to the normal loan period and disbursement timing rules for Direct Loans when clinical work that meets the criteria described above is included in a standard term. Nonstandard Terms Generally, nonstandard terms are terms that are not semesters, trimesters, or quarters. For example, a 5-week term or a 23-week term would be considered a nonstandard term because no standard term can be fewer than nine weeks or greater than 21 weeks in length. Like standard terms, nonstandard terms may be equal in length or may be of different lengths. If a program is offered in a combination of standard terms and nonstandard terms, the program is considered to be offered in nonstandard terms. Also, like standard terms, nonstandard terms may not overlap within a program. Even if a school calls its terms semesters, trimesters, or quarters, they are considered to be nonstandard terms if they do not comply with the policy on standard term length, as described earlier. For instance, a 22-week semester or an 8-week quarter must be treated as a nonstandard term, because a semester cannot contain more than 21 weeks and a quarter must include a minimum of nine weeks. Semesters, trimesters, or quarters are also considered to be nonstandard terms if academic progress is not measured in the manner normally associated with the type of term. For example, if a program is offered in 15-week semesters but measures academic progress in quarter credit hours, the semesters would be considered nonstandard terms.']
reference: Inclusion of clinical work in a standard term depends on several criteria: all students must participate in the practicum or clinical experience, and it must be a requirement for licensure or practice; the school has little or no control over the timing of the clinical work, which may be due to external licensing bodies or scheduling needs; and the credit hours for the clinical work must be associated with the term during which most of the training occurs, even if the dates overlap or do not align exactly. If these conditions are met, terms including such clinical work are not considered nonstandard, even if they overlap with other terms. This flexibility applies specifically to clinical work in programs like medicine, nursing, veterinary, dentistry, pharmacy, physical therapy, and student teaching for teaching certificates. Conversely, nonstandard terms are those that do not conform to typical lengths, such as less than nine weeks or more than 21 weeks, or if academic progress is measured differently from standard practices. Therefore, clinical work meeting all the specified criteria can allow a term to be classified as standard despite overlaps or irregularities.

user_input: Can you explain how Title IV regulations apply to programs that are not based on traditional terms?
reference_contexts: ['Non-Term Characteristics A program that measures progress in clock hours is always treated as a non-term program. Except for subscription-based programs, a program that measures progress in credit-hours is considered to have a non- term calendar if it has: Courses that do not begin and end within a set period of time such as a term; Courses that overlap terms; Self-paced and independent study courses that overlap terms; or Sequential courses that do not begin and end within a term. Payment Periods The payment period is applicable to all Title IV programs except the Federal Work-Study (FWS) Program. For example, Title IV program disbursements (except FWS payments) must be made on a payment period basis, as discussed in detail']
reference: Payment periods under Title IV are applicable to all programs except the Federal Work-Study (FWS) Program. For example, Title IV program disbursements, excluding FWS payments, must be made on a payment period basis. The context also indicates that programs measuring progress in clock hours or credit-hours without a set term are considered non-term programs, which relates to how Title IV regulations are applied.

user_input: How are academic calendars defined for different programs?
reference_contexts: ['Chapter 1 Academic Years, Academic Calendars, Payment Periods, and Disbursements Academic Year Requirements Every eligible program must have a defined academic year. A school may have different academic years for different academic programs. For example, a school may choose to define the academic year for a term-based program differently from a non-term program. In some cases, the academic year definition must be different for different programs, such as in the case of a clock-hour program and a credit-hour program. For Title IV purposes, the academic year is defined in weeks of instructional time and credit or clock hours. The program9s academic year does not have to coincide with the school9s academic calendar (see <Academic year definition and effect on awards= later in the chapter). A school may treat two versions of the same academic program (day and night, for example) as separate programs and define different academic years for each version. If a school establishes separate versions of a program, with different academic years, but allows individual students to take courses from both versions, it must be able to demonstrate which program the student is actually enrolled in. Generally, to be considered enrolled in a particular program or version of a program, a student must be taking most of their coursework in that program. Although a school may have different academic years for different programs, it must use the same academic year definition for all Title IV awards for students enrolled in a particular program, and for all other Title IV program purposes. Weeks of Instructional Time in an Academic Year For both undergraduate and graduate programs, the law and regulations require an academic year to include a minimum number of weeks of instructional time. For a program offered in credit hours, the academic year must include at least 30 weeks of instructional time. For a program offered in clock hours, the academic year must include at least 26 weeks of instructional time. Note: See Volume 2, Chapter 2 for information about academic year requirements for direct assessment programs, which do not measure academic progress using credit or clock hours. The number of weeks of instructional time is based on the period that generally begins on the first day of classes in the academic year and ends on the last day of classes or the last day of examinations, whichever is later. Schools that provide 2- or 4-year associate or baccalaureate degree programs may apply to the Department if they want to request approval to establish a full academic year of less than 30 weeks of instructional time. The Department is permitted to grant a reduction for good cause to no less than 26 weeks of instructional time. These requests are handled on a case-by-case basis. To request approval, contact the School Participation Division that oversees your school. A listing of contact information for the regional School Participation Divisions can be found in the Knowledge Center. For all Title IV programs, a week of instructional time is any period of seven consecutive days in which 3 At least one day of regularly scheduled instruction or examinations occurs, or, after the last scheduled day of classes']
reference: Academic calendars are defined for each program, which may have different academic years, such as for term-based or non-term programs, and can vary between clock-hour and credit-hour programs. Schools must demonstrate which program a student is enrolled in, especially if different academic years are established for different versions of a program. The academic year is based on weeks of instructional time, with at least 30 weeks for credit-hour programs and 26 weeks for clock-hour programs, and must align with Title IV requirements.

user_input: Include clinical work in standard term periods and non-term characteers how do they relate?
reference_contexts:
['<1-hop>

Inclusion of Clinical Work in a Standard Term Periods of medical and education program clinical work which is conducted outside the classroom may not be included in a standard term, unless all of the following apply: All students in the program must participate in the practicum or clinical experience, and they must be required to complete the practicum or clinical experience as a condition for applying for licensure or authorization to practice the occupation they intend to pursue; The school has little or no control over the length or starting and ending dates of the practicum or clinical experience. This may be due to constraints imposed by outside licensing bodies or the need to accommodate schedules of entities with which students are being placed (e.g., school districts or hospitals); and Credit hours associated with the practicum or clinical experience must be associated with the term in which most of the training occurs, even if the starting and ending dates do not exactly align with the term dates and/or overlap with another term. If the clinical work meets all the above criteria, terms which include such clinical work are not required to be considered nonstandard, nor are such programs required to be considered non-term, even if the clinical work overlaps another term. This flexibility is limited to required clinical periods associated with standard term programs in medicine (including, but not limited to, allopathic, osteopathic, nursing, veterinary, dentistry, pharmacy, and physical therapy), and student teaching required to obtain a state teaching certificate. See Volume 8, Chapter 3 for additional guidance on certain exceptions to the normal loan period and disbursement timing rules for Direct Loans when clinical work that meets the criteria described above is included in a standard term. Nonstandard Terms Generally, nonstandard terms are terms that are not semesters, trimesters, or quarters. For example, a 5-week term or a 23-week term would be considered a nonstandard term because no standard term can be fewer than nine weeks or greater than 21 weeks in length. Like standard terms, nonstandard terms may be equal in length or may be of different lengths. If a program is offered in a combination of standard terms and nonstandard terms, the program is considered to be offered in nonstandard terms. Also, like standard terms, nonstandard terms may not overlap within a program. Even if a school calls its terms semesters, trimesters, or quarters, they are considered to be nonstandard terms if they do not comply with the policy on standard term length, as described earlier. For instance, a 22-week semester or an 8-week quarter must be treated as a nonstandard term, because a semester cannot contain more than 21 weeks and a quarter must include a minimum of nine weeks. Semesters, trimesters, or quarters are also considered to be nonstandard terms if academic progress is not measured in the manner normally associated with the type of term. For example, if a program is offered in 15-week semesters but measures academic progress in quarter credit hours, the semesters would be considered nonstandard terms.', '<2-hop>

If the clinical work meets all the above criteria, terms which include such clinical work are not required to be considered nonstandard, nor are such programs required to be considered non-term, even if the clinical work overlaps another term. This flexibility is limited to required clinical periods associated with standard term programs in medicine (including, but not limited to, allopathic, osteopathic, nursing, veterinary, dentistry, pharmacy, and physical therapy), and student teaching required to obtain a state teaching certificate. See Volume 8, Chapter 3 for additional guidance on certain exceptions to the normal loan period and disbursement timing rules for Direct Loans when clinical work that meets the criteria described above is included in a standard term. Nonstandard Terms Generally, nonstandard terms are terms that are not semesters, trimesters, or quarters. For example, a 5-week term or a 23-week term would be considered a nonstandard term because no standard term can be fewer than nine weeks or greater than 21 weeks in length. Like standard terms, nonstandard terms may be equal in length or may be of different lengths. If a program is offered in a combination of standard terms and nonstandard terms, the program is considered to be offered in nonstandard terms. Also, like standard terms, nonstandard terms may not overlap within a program. Even if a school calls its terms semesters, trimesters, or quarters, they are considered to be nonstandard terms if they do not comply with the policy on standard term length, as described earlier. For instance, a 22-week semester or an 8-week quarter must be treated as a nonstandard term, because a semester cannot contain more than 21 weeks and a quarter must include a minimum of nine weeks. Semesters, trimesters, or quarters are also considered to be nonstandard terms if academic progress is not measured in the manner normally associated with the type of term. For example, if a program is offered in 15-week semesters but measures academic progress in quarter credit hours, the semesters would be considered nonstandard terms.', '<3-hop>

Except for subscription-based programs, a program that measures progress in credit-hours is considered to have a non- term calendar if it has: Courses that do not begin and end within a set period of time such as a term; Courses that overlap terms; Self-paced and independent study courses that overlap terms; or Sequential courses that do not begin and end within a term. For example, Title IV program disbursements (except FWS payments) must be made on a payment period basis, as discussed in detail']

If these criteria are met, such clinical work does not make the program non-standard or non-term. Additionally, non-term characteristics include programs that measure progress in clock hours, have courses that do not fit within set periods, or overlap terms, which are considered non-term programs. Therefore, clinical work that meets the inclusion criteria aligns with standard term characteristics, whereas programs with non-term features are characterized by flexible or overlapping courses and progress measurement methods.

user_input: How do Chapters 2 and 3 collectively address the requirements for defining academic years, instructional time, and clinical work inclusion in standard and nonstandard terms to ensure compliance with federal regulations for Title IV programs?

['<1-hop>

A school may have different academic years for different academic programs. For example, a school may choose to define the academic year for a term-based program differently from a non-term program. If a school establishes separate versions of a program, with different academic years, but allows individual students to take courses from both versions, it must be able to demonstrate which program the student is actually enrolled in. Generally, to be considered enrolled in a particular program or version of a program, a student must be taking most of their coursework in that program. Although a school may have different academic years for different programs, it must use the same academic year definition for all Title IV awards for students enrolled in a particular program, and for all other Title IV program purposes. For a program offered in clock hours, the academic year must include at least 26 weeks of instructional time. For example, a 5-week term or a 23-week term would be considered a nonstandard term because no standard term can be fewer than nine weeks or greater than 21 weeks in length. reference: Chapter 2 details the requirements for establishing academic years, including the minimum weeks of instructional time—at least 30 weeks for credit-hour programs and 26 weeks for clock-hour programs—and emphasizes that the academic year does not need to align with the school’s overall calendar. It also discusses the possibility of requesting approval for shorter academic years under certain conditions. Chapter 3 explains the inclusion of clinical work in standard term periods, specifying that clinical experiences conducted outside the classroom can be included if all students participate, the school has limited control over clinical dates, and credit hours are associated with the training period. Additionally, it clarifies the classification of nonstandard terms, such as shorter or overlapping terms, and how they are treated under regulations, including the measurement of academic progress. Together, these chapters provide comprehensive guidance on defining academic years, instructional time, and clinical work inclusion, ensuring programs meet federal standards for Title IV eligibility and compliance.

user_input: How do different academic years for programs affect compliance with federal instructional time requirements?
reference_contexts:
['<1-hop>

Chapter 1 Academic Years, Academic Calendars, Payment Periods, and Disbursements Academic Year Requirements Every eligible program must have a defined academic year. A school may have different academic years for different academic programs. For example, a school may choose to define the academic year for a term-based program differently from a non-term program. In some cases, the academic year definition must be different for different programs, such as in the case of a clock-hour program and a credit-hour program. For Title IV purposes, the academic year is defined in weeks of instructional time and credit or clock hours. The program9s academic year does not have to coincide with the school9s academic calendar (see <Academic year definition and effect on awards= later in the chapter). A school may treat two versions of the same academic program (day and night, for example) as separate programs and define different academic years for each version. If a school establishes separate versions of a program, with different academic years, but allows individual students to take courses from both versions, it must be able to demonstrate which program the student is actually enrolled in. Generally, to be considered enrolled in a particular program or version of a program, a student must be taking most of their coursework in that program. Although a school may have different academic years for different programs, it must use the same academic year definition for all Title IV awards for students enrolled in a particular program, and for all other Title IV program purposes. Weeks of Instructional Time in an Academic Year For both undergraduate and graduate programs, the law and regulations require an academic year to include a minimum number of weeks of instructional time. For a program offered in credit hours, the academic year must include at least 30 weeks of instructional time. For a program offered in clock hours, the academic year must include at least 26 weeks of instructional time. Note: See Volume 2, Chapter 2 for information about academic year requirements for direct assessment programs, which do not measure academic progress using credit or clock hours. The number of weeks of instructional time is based on the period that generally begins on the first day of classes in the academic year and ends on the last day of classes or the last day of examinations, whichever is later. Schools that provide 2- or 4-year associate or baccalaureate degree programs may apply to the Department if they want to request approval to establish a full academic year of less than 30 weeks of instructional time. The Department is permitted to grant a reduction for good cause to no less than 26 weeks of instructional time. These requests are handled on a case-by-case basis. To request approval, contact the School Participation Division that oversees your school. A listing of contact information for the regional School Participation Divisions can be found in the Knowledge Center. For all Title IV programs, a week of instructional time is any period of seven consecutive days in which 3 At least one day of regularly scheduled instruction or examinations occurs, or, after the last scheduled day of classes', '<2-hop>

Chapter 1 Academic Years, Academic Calendars, Payment Periods, and Disbursements Academic Year Requirements Every eligible program must have a defined academic year. A school may have different academic years for different academic programs. For example, a school may choose to define the academic year for a term-based program differently from a non-term program. In some cases, the academic year definition must be different for different programs, such as in the case of a clock-hour program and a credit-hour program. For Title IV purposes, the academic year is defined in weeks of instructional time and credit or clock hours. The program9s academic year does not have to coincide with the school9s academic calendar (see <Academic year definition and effect on awards= later in the chapter). A school may treat two versions of the same academic program (day and night, for example) as separate programs and define different academic years for each version. If a school establishes separate versions of a program, with different academic years, but allows individual students to take courses from both versions, it must be able to demonstrate which program the student is actually enrolled in. Generally, to be considered enrolled in a particular program or version of a program, a student must be taking most of their coursework in that program. Although a school may have different academic years for different programs, it must use the same academic year definition for all Title IV awards for students enrolled in a particular program, and for all other Title IV program purposes. Weeks of Instructional Time in an Academic Year For both undergraduate and graduate programs, the law and regulations require an academic year to include a minimum number of weeks of instructional time. For a program offered in credit hours, the academic year must include at least 30 weeks of instructional time. For a program offered in clock hours, the academic year must include at least 26 weeks of instructional time. Note: See Volume 2, Chapter 2 for information about academic year requirements for direct assessment programs, which do not measure academic progress using credit or clock hours. The number of weeks of instructional time is based on the period that generally begins on the first day of classes in the academic year and ends on the last day of classes or the last day of examinations, whichever is later. Schools that provide 2- or 4-year associate or baccalaureate degree programs may apply to the Department if they want to request approval to establish a full academic year of less than 30 weeks of instructional time. The Department is permitted to grant a reduction for good cause to no less than 26 weeks of instructional time. These requests are handled on a case-by-case basis. To request approval, contact the School Participation Division that oversees your school. A listing of contact information for the regional School Participation Divisions can be found in the Knowledge Center. For all Title IV programs, a week of instructional time is any period of seven consecutive days in which 3 At least one day of regularly scheduled instruction or examinations occurs, or, after the last scheduled day of classes']
reference: Different academic years for various programs are permissible as long as each program's academic year is defined consistently for all Title IV awards and purposes. For example, a school may define separate academic years for credit-hour and clock-hour programs, which must include at least 30 and 26 weeks of instructional time respectively. These definitions ensure compliance with federal requirements, even if the academic years do not coincide with the overall school calendar. Additionally, schools can request approval to establish shorter academic years, as long as they meet the minimum instructional weeks, to maintain program eligibility and proper disbursement of federal aid.

user_input: How does Volume 8 address inclusion of clinical work in standard terms for programs with nonstandard terms?
reference_contexts:
['<1-hop>

Inclusion of Clinical Work in a Standard Term Periods of medical and education program clinical work which is conducted outside the classroom may not be included in a standard term, unless all of the following apply: All students in the program must participate in the practicum or clinical experience, and they must be required to complete the practicum or clinical experience as a condition for applying for licensure or authorization to practice the occupation they intend to pursue; The school has little or no control over the length or starting and ending dates of the practicum or clinical experience. This may be due to constraints imposed by outside licensing bodies or the need to accommodate schedules of entities with which students are being placed (e.g., school districts or hospitals); and Credit hours associated with the practicum or clinical experience must be associated with the term in which most of the training occurs, even if the starting and ending dates do not exactly align with the term dates and/or overlap with another term. If the clinical work meets all the above criteria, terms which include such clinical work are not required to be considered nonstandard, nor are such programs required to be considered non-term, even if the clinical work overlaps another term. This flexibility is limited to required clinical periods associated with standard term programs in medicine (including, but not limited to, allopathic, osteopathic, nursing, veterinary, dentistry, pharmacy, and physical therapy), and student teaching required to obtain a state teaching certificate. See Volume 8, Chapter 3 for additional guidance on certain exceptions to the normal loan period and disbursement timing rules for Direct Loans when clinical work that meets the criteria described above is included in a standard term. Nonstandard Terms Generally, nonstandard terms are terms that are not semesters, trimesters, or quarters. For example, a 5-week term or a 23-week term would be considered a nonstandard term because no standard term can be fewer than nine weeks or greater than 21 weeks in length. Like standard terms, nonstandard terms may be equal in length or may be of different lengths. If a program is offered in a combination of standard terms and nonstandard terms, the program is considered to be offered in nonstandard terms. Also, like standard terms, nonstandard terms may not overlap within a program. Even if a school calls its terms semesters, trimesters, or quarters, they are considered to be nonstandard terms if they do not comply with the policy on standard term length, as described earlier. For instance, a 22-week semester or an 8-week quarter must be treated as a nonstandard term, because a semester cannot contain more than 21 weeks and a quarter must include a minimum of nine weeks. Semesters, trimesters, or quarters are also considered to be nonstandard terms if academic progress is not measured in the manner normally associated with the type of term. For example, if a program is offered in 15-week semesters but measures academic progress in quarter credit hours, the semesters would be considered nonstandard terms.', '<2-hop>

Inclusion of Clinical Work in a Standard Term Periods of medical and education program clinical work which is conducted outside the classroom may not be included in a standard term, unless all of the following apply: All students in the program must participate in the practicum or clinical experience, and they must be required to complete the practicum or clinical experience as a condition for applying for licensure or authorization to practice the occupation they intend to pursue; The school has little or no control over the length or starting and ending dates of the practicum or clinical experience. This may be due to constraints imposed by outside licensing bodies or the need to accommodate schedules of entities with which students are being placed (e.g., school districts or hospitals); and Credit hours associated with the practicum or clinical experience must be associated with the term in which most of the training occurs, even if the starting and ending dates do not exactly align with the term dates and/or overlap with another term. If the clinical work meets all the above criteria, terms which include such clinical work are not required to be considered nonstandard, nor are such programs required to be considered non-term, even if the clinical work overlaps another term. This flexibility is limited to required clinical periods associated with standard term programs in medicine (including, but not limited to, allopathic, osteopathic, nursing, veterinary, dentistry, pharmacy, and physical therapy), and student teaching required to obtain a state teaching certificate. See Volume 8, Chapter 3 for additional guidance on certain exceptions to the normal loan period and disbursement timing rules for Direct Loans when clinical work that meets the criteria described above is included in a standard term. Nonstandard Terms Generally, nonstandard terms are terms that are not semesters, trimesters, or quarters. For example, a 5-week term or a 23-week term would be considered a nonstandard term because no standard term can be fewer than nine weeks or greater than 21 weeks in length. Like standard terms, nonstandard terms may be equal in length or may be of different lengths. If a program is offered in a combination of standard terms and nonstandard terms, the program is considered to be offered in nonstandard terms. Also, like standard terms, nonstandard terms may not overlap within a program. Even if a school calls its terms semesters, trimesters, or quarters, they are considered to be nonstandard terms if they do not comply with the policy on standard term length, as described earlier. For instance, a 22-week semester or an 8-week quarter must be treated as a nonstandard term, because a semester cannot contain more than 21 weeks and a quarter must include a minimum of nine weeks. Semesters, trimesters, or quarters are also considered to be nonstandard terms if academic progress is not measured in the manner normally associated with the type of term. For example, if a program is offered in 15-week semesters but measures academic progress in quarter credit hours, the semesters would be considered nonstandard terms.']
reference: Volume 8 explains that clinical work conducted outside the classroom may be included in a standard term if all students participate in required practicum or clinical experiences necessary for licensure, and if the school has little control over the clinical schedule. It also states that programs with nonstandard terms, such as those shorter than nine weeks or longer than 21 weeks, are considered nonstandard, and clinical work meeting the specified criteria can be included in standard terms regardless of overlaps, provided the clinical requirements are met as outlined in Volume 8, Chapter 3.
